In contrast to the E. coli isolates, the majority of the enterococcal isolates in the present study were found to be AMR and the single highest resistance was to @sm$ lincomycin @/sm$. In surface water samples collected in an area with intensive poultry production, the highest level of resistance among 36 enterococcal isolates was to @sm$ lincomycin @/sm$ (88%), followed by tetracycline (24%). Although @sm$ lincomycin @/sm$ is commonly used in poultry production, we have not previously detected @sm$ lincomycin @/sm$ residues in the USR watershed, which is not surprising given that it is not approved for use in dairy cattle in the United States. showed that the most common AMR phenotype among enterococcal isolates from dairy cattle was to @sm$ lincomycin @/sm$ (587/636; 92%). In addition, they detected at least 10 enterococcal species and @sm$ lincomycin @/sm$-resistant isolates were abundant among each of the different species. Similarly, 10 different enterococcal species were detected in surface water samples from the Upper Oconee watershed and the majority (564/637; 89%) were resistant to @sm$ lincomycin @/sm$. In the present study, seven out of eight enterococcal species (except E. malodoratus) were resistant to @sm$ lincomycin @/sm$ (range of 49-100% isolates per species). The high rate of @sm$ lincomycin @/sm$ resistance among enterococci is likely not a result of exposure to the antimicrobial, but due to the fact that most enterococci, with the exception of E. durans, are intrinsically resistant to @sm$ lincomycin @/sm$.

However, in our trials, different behaviors of tyramine and 2-phenylethylamine accumulation were observed in relation to the strain. In particular, strains belonging to the same species (E. faecalis or @gm$ E. faecium @/gm$) were characterized by different responses indicating that, if the presence of tyrDC is common among enterococci, the decarboxylating potential can be extremely variable. The transcriptional analyses of the gene tyrDC confirmed these observations. In recent years, a number of studies have been conducted to evaluate the gene expression level of amino acid decarboxylases on the @sm$ BAs @/sm$ accumulation in different food and model systems. However, up to now no studies have compared the tyrDC transcript levels in enterococcal strains of the same species. In the present study a variability of the tyrDC gene expression in different strains of E. faecalis and @gm$ E. faecium @/gm$ was evidenced for the first time. The two strains with the higher decarboxylating potential (E. faecalis EF 37 and @gm$ E. faecium @/gm$ FC12) were characterized by a higher transcription of tyrDC after 2 h of incubation and the maintenance of a remarkably higher transcription level throughout all the incubation period considered here.

Interestingly this ecotin homolog was present in specific non-thermophilic Campylobacters primarily described to inhabit the oral cavity and associated with the onset of periodontitis, an inflammatory disease caused by a consortium of microbes and host defense mechanisms. Here, bacterial killing by neutrophils comes as a double-edged sword; @sm$ reactive oxygen species @/sm$ and bactericidal proteins such as elastase not only neutralize bacteria, but also damage host tissues and increase the severity and progression of periodontal diseases. C. rectus, in particular, is a pathogen detected at elevated levels in diseased human subgingival sites when compared to healthy non-diseased controls and is often associated with other oral pathogens such as Porphyromonas gingivalis. Other @gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$ species isolated from oral sites include Campylobacter showae, Campylobacter curvus, Campylobacter concisus, Campylobacter sputorum and @gm$ Campylobacter hominis @/gm$. In these @gm$ Campylobacter @/gm$ species, the N-glycan is also believed to protect glycoproteins from proteolysis, however, ecotin might provide an additional survival advantage in the periodontal pockets that contain high levels of neutrophil serine proteases.

smithii plays an important role in the efficient digestion of polysaccharides with complex chemical structures (highly enriched in the buttered milk tea due to the addition of roasted barley), by both optimizing @sm$ hydrogen @/sm$ levels for bacterial polysaccharide digestion and consuming the end products of bacterial fermentation. Interestingly, upon bacteria-archaea correlation analysis, a number of SCFAs-producing bacteria (including @gm$ R. faecis @/gm$, C. aerofaciens, and P. copri) which carry out anti-inflammatory functions were found to have positive associations with M. smithii, hinting at mutualistic/syntrophic versus antagonistic relationships between gut bacteria and archaea. A prominent example of bacterial-archaeal syntrophism was previously established for Ruminococcus and methanogens, where the methanogens consume @sm$ H2 @/sm$, allowing Ruminococcus to produce twice as many ATP molecules from the same amount of substrate. From our data, Prevotella, Ruminococcus, Collinsella, and Methanobrevibacter may form a syntrophic guild specified for the degradation of starches and complex polysaccharides contained in rural and ethnic diets, as well as for SCFA generation and depletion of gut @sm$ H2 @/sm$. This is also reflected in our observation that rural residents had an increased abundance of SCFA (pyruvate) fermentation module in the gut archaeome, compared to urban residents. Prevotella assists in breaking down carbohydrate/fiber-rich foods into simpler sugars (poly- and monosaccharides) and other products (such as succinate) to be fermented by bacteria such as Ruminococcus and Collinsella. Fermentation byproducts (including @sm$ H2 @/sm$ and acetate-/H+) produced would then be consumed by Methanobrevibacter with the subsequent production of CO2 and/or CH4.

used OG in conjunction with photodynamic inactivation (PDI) by blue light (BL) to eradicate bacteria and eliminate biofilms of @gm$ Pseudomonas fluorescens @/gm$. In this study, PDI operated through the interaction of applied BL, the exogenous photosensitizer OG, and oxygen to produce @sm$ ROS @/sm$ within the cell, which destroy intracellular lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids, and kill the bacterium. OG and BL administered individually exhibited some bactericidal effect, but BL irradiation with 0.4 mM of OG killed a significant amount of @gm$ P. fluorescens @/gm$ cells in suspension, and S. aureus showed even higher susceptibility. BL also boosted the uptake of OG into cells, and BL + OG seriously damaged cell walls and caused cells to disgorge cytoplasm and collapse. Production of  OH resulted in lethal oxidative damage to lipids, proteins, and DNA. BL also enhanced the inhibition of biofilm formation by OG, and the combination was able to efficiently eradicate established biofilms. In a further experiment, the authors tested the efficacy of electrospun poly(lactic-acid) nanofiber-based packaging material in combination with OG and irradiated with BL for reducing the microbial contamination of giant salamander meat (a culinary delicacy and medicinal in traditional Chinese medicine) by @gm$ P. fluorescens @/gm$; 30 min of treatment reduced the bacteria count by approximately 99%, indicating that active OG/PLA nanofibers can be used to prolong the shelf life of perishable foods.

vulgare SPU B805, Pseudomonas putida KT2440, Paracoccus denitrificans PD1222, Bacillus licheniformis and @gm$ Raoultella ornithinolytica @/gm$ due to their good qualities and immense importance in metabolic engineering. K. vulgare SPU B805, another 2-KGA-producing strain, can convert L-sorbose to 2-KGA with high efficiency when co-cultured with companion strain. P. putida KT2440 is a good chassis for the production of various industrial products such as n-butanol, @sm$ vanillin @/sm$, and ethanol because of its versatile metabolism and low nutritional requirements. P. denitrificans PD1222, a soil-denitrifying bacterium, is considered as one of the best sources for polyhydroxyalkanoate (PHA) production because the strain can accumulate high yield in the cells, and can use a wide variety of industrial wastes as carbon sources to produce target products. B. licheniformis, as a generally regarded as a safe (GRAS) strain with the qualified characteristics of fast growth rate and strong sugar consumption, is usually used to produce 2,3-butanediol (BDO), and is also a good chassis strain for the production of acetoin, a common additive in the food industry and a building block for chemical materials. @gm$ R. ornithinolytica @/gm$ can be used to produce 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), an important renewable biotechnological building block. Moreover, @gm$ R. ornithinolytica @/gm$ has great biotechnology potential for its ability to produce biomolecules of industrial significance, such as 2,3-butanediol (2,3 BD), pullulanase and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA).
